post0.title: Honhum
post0.content: { “cells”: [ { “cell_type”: “markdown”, “metadata”: {}, “source”: [ “ n”, “# Elements of design n”, “are structural parts of a work of art, which must be used according to principles of design in order to produce satisfactory work. Design is a structure of art with the elements and principles unifying the different parts and giving the work visual order. The elements and principles are always used in combination and therefore work together to create a work of art with good design. n”, “ n”, “### SPACE: n”, “is absolutely necessary to all works of art because other elements are composed and developed within it. It can extend in either two (2-D) or three (3-D) dimensions. Space has no meaning until its limits are determined and its existence used. n”, “ n”, “### FORMAT: n”, “once an artist has determined the size and shape of the area in which a work of art will be created, that area is referred to as the format. n”, “### POSITIVE SPACE: n”, “the interior area of a shape, object, or form. n”, “### NEGATIVE SPACE: n”, “the area exterior to, surrounding, or between shapes, objects, or forms. n”, “ n”, “### LINE: n”, “is a basic structural element of art; all works of art have linear aspects. Paul Klee said, “A line is a dot going for a walk.” Lines may express response or excitement, strength or weakness, or other conditions. Lines have five characteristics: n”, “ n”, “### LENGTH: n”, “short, long, continuous. n”, “### WIDTH: n”, “thick, thin, carrying n”, “### ATTITUDE: n”, “ vertical, horizontal, diagonal n”, “### CURVATURE: n”, “straight, shallow, tight n”, “### TEXTURE: n”, “hard, soft, vibrant n”, “ n”, “### SHAPE: n”, “the shape is produced by a continuous line connecting with itself; is usually regarded as a two-dimensional flat object. n”, “ n”, “### FORM: n”, “usually regarded as three-dimensional objects or a shape that has the appearance of depth. n”, “ n”, “### MASS: n”, “Bulk, weight, and density of three-dimensional forms, either actual or implied. n”, “ n”, “### VOLUME: n”, “Any three-dimensional quantity that is bound or enclosed, whether solid or void. n”, “ n”, “### COLOR: n”, “is a quality of visual sensation usually evoked by light stimulating the cones of the retina of the eye. Color has four qualities: n”, “ n”, “### HUE: n”, “the generic name of a color, such as red, yellow, etc. n”, “### INTENSITY: n”, “the brightness or dullness of a color. n”, “### VALUE: n”, “the lightness or darkness of a color. Helps us understand two-dimensional art n”, “### TEMPERATURE: n”, “the warm or cool quality in the appearance of a color, for example orange is a warm color, and green is a cool color. n”, “ n”, “### TEXTURE: n”, “denotes the surface tactile qualities, usually described as being rough, smooth, coarse or fine, shiny or dull. The texture is understood through the sense of light. n”, “### TRUE (actual) TEXTURE: n”, “occurs when the surface feels as it appears. Easily found in nature. n”, “### FALSE (implied) TEXTURE: n”, “occurs when the actual surface appears to be a texture other than what it is; usually found in works of art. n”, “ n”, “# Principles of Design n”, “A principle is a rule to be followed in creating a design or composition. Design in the structure of art, with the elements and principles unifying the different parts and giving the work visual order. The elements and principles are always used in combination and therefore work together to create a work of art with good design. n”, “ n”, “### BALANCE: n”, “equality of visual weight achieved through the use of one or more elements or design. n”, “### SYMMETRICAL: n”, “(formal) BALANCE: occurs when the elements on one side of the center are identical (but mirrored) to those of the other side. n”, “### Asymmetrical: n”, “(informal) BALANCE: occurs when the elements on one side of the center are not identical to those on the other, yet appear visually equal. n”, “### RADIAL BALANCE: n”, “is similar to formal balance, but based on a circle with the center focal point. n”, “ n”, “### UNITY: n”, “harmonious relationship of parts creating a single main idea, emotion, or point of view; obtained by relating elements of design to each other. n”, “### REPETITION: n”, “unity is obtained by repeating specific elements of design to produce patterns and rhythms. n”, “### PROGRESSION n”, “(movement): elements that cause the eye to move through a composition. n”, “ n”, “### PATTERN: n”, “pattern uses the art elements in planned or random repetitions to enhance surfaces of paintings or sculptures. Patterns often occur in nature, and artists use similar repeated motifs to create patterns in their work. Pattern increases visual excitement by enriching the surface interest. n”, “ n”, “### MOVEMENT: n”, “Artists to direct viewers through their work, often to focal areas, use visual movement. Such movement can be directed along lines, edges, shapes, and colors within works, but moves the eye most easily on the paths of equal value. n”, “ n”, “<- Ex: bc lines are used to replicate movement when not moving n”, “ n”, “### EMPHASIS: n”, “that part of a composition that is most important presents the main idea of the work of art. n”, “### DOMINANCE: n”, “provides a center of interest, attracts attention, or makes one part of the composition appear most important. n”, “### DOMINANT: n”, “the most prominent principle of the most obvious in the influence of position. n”, “### THEME & VARIATION: n”, “an idea or dominant feature that gives the artwork its character; the subject of a work of art, sometimes with a number of phases or different examples. n”, “### SUBORDINATION: n”, “(sub-dominance): those elements that are less dominating but provide interest and background into the composition. n”, “### REST AREAS: n”, “those places within a composition that are relatively vacant, often regarded as negative shapes or spaces. n”, “ n”, “### RHYTHM: n”, “visual movement achieved as the viewer’s eyes progress throughout a composition, moving and resting in regular or varied measures. n”, “### REPETITION: n”, “of colors, shapes, textures, lines, etc. n”, “ n”, “### HARMONY: n”, “the appearance of visual order obtained by relating elements of design to each other to create a sense of unity. n”, “### APPROPRIATENESS: n”, “suitability of fitness of an idea, theme motif, or purpose to elements, media, or materials used in the creation of a work of art. n” ] }, { “cell_type”: “markdown”, “metadata”: {}, “source”: [] } ], “metadata”: { “kernelspec”: { “display_name”: “Python 3.10.6 64-bit”, “language”: “python”, “name”: “python3” }, “language_info”: { “name”: “python”, “version”: “3.10.6” }, “orig_nbformat”: 4, “vscode”: { “interpreter”: { “hash”: “82faa6d27c9a927522682e95cb30c684238aba2a31347a70411ee016fed8cfe5” } } }, “nbformat”: 4, “nbformat_minor”: 2 } .

post1.title: Apbio
post1.content: AP Biology . Chapter and Section Evolution Figures #1 (7.1) Evolution A pattern and process Evolution is NOT goal oriented Individual organisms do not evolve. Populations evolve Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium allows us to mathematically calculate allele frequency Evolution is pressured and driven by environment Variation Traits are heritable Some organisms (i.e. spores & humans) overproduce purposely Overproduction is done as when there are low-resources, not all offspring survive - overproduction ensures that at least some organisms survive. Three types of selection Directionaly Stationary Disruptive Microevolution Evolution of a group or species occurring over a small period of time

post2.title: Title
post2.content: import getpass, sys from tkinter.messagebox import QUESTION, YES def question (question, answer): ans = input(question) if ans == answer: print("Correct!") elif ans == "No": sys.exit() else: print("Wrong") def question (question, answer): ans = input(question) question("You are about to take an awesome short quiz. Ready? (Yes or No)" , "Yes") question("What is 5 x 8?" , "40") question("How many states are there in the United States of America?" , "50") # if points == 3: # print("Congrats! ") # elif points == 2: # print("Not bad, keep working! " ) # else: # print("Its okay, better luck next time!") .

post3.title: Bash Jupyter Notebook
post3.content: echo "Using conditional statement to create a project directory and project" # Variable section export project_dir=$HOME/vscode4 # change vscode to different name to test git clone export project=$project_dir/APCSP # change APCSP to name of project from git clone export project_repo="https://github.com/nighthawkcoders/APCSP.git" # change to project of choice cd ~ # start in home directory # Conditional block to make a project directory if [ ! -d $project_dir ] then echo "Directory $project_dir does not exists... makinng directory $project_dir" mkdir -p $project_dir fi echo "Directory $project_dir exists." # Conditional block to git clone a project from project_repo if [ ! -d $project ] then echo "Directory $project does not exists... cloning $project_repo" cd $project_dir git clone $project_repo cd ~ fi echo "Directory $project exists." . Input In [1] echo "Using conditional statement to create a project directory and project" ^ SyntaxError: invalid syntax . echo "Navigate to project, then navigate to area wwhere files were cloned" cd $project pwd echo "" echo "list top level or root of files with project pulled from github" ls echo "" echo "list again with hidden files pulled from github" ls -a # hidden files flag, many shell commands have flags echo "" echo "list all files in long format" ls -al . echo "Look for posts" export posts=$project/_posts # _posts inside project cd $posts # this should exist per fastpages pwd # present working directory ls -l .

post5.title: Ethan's First Notebook
post5.content: Printing "Hello" . print("Hello") . Hello . Time value of money after one year calculator! . With this calculator that I made, you can insert any initial amount of money and any interest rate. In this demo, I started with $1000 and used an interest rate of 0.1563. . print("Lets calculate your time value of money after one year!") print("How much money are you investing?") # Input the initial amount of money Money = float(input("Amount of money: ")) print("$" + "{:.2f}".format(Money)) # Input interest rate print("What is the interest rate of your investment?") r = float(input("Interest rate: ")) percent = (r * 100) # Interest rate shown as a percentage print("{:.2f}".format(percent) + "%") # Calculation of the final amount of money final_amount = (Money * (1 + r)) print('This will be your amount of money after one year.') print("$" + "{:.2f}".format(final_amount)) . Lets calculate your time value of money after one year! How much money are you investing? $50.00 What is the interest rate of your investment? 15.00% This will be your amount of money after one year. $57.50 .
